questions.text: Which is the most abundant protein in bone?
questions.solution:
The organic component is dominated by type I collagen that forms the basic architecture of bone on which inorganic portion is deposited. Support to collagen is provided by derived protein components like proteoglycans, glycoproteins, phospholipids and phosphoproteins that serve specific functions.



REF- Manish kumar Varshney 1st edition, Page no 3.

choices.text: Sub coracoid is the most common type
There will be inability to touch the opposite shoulder
The anterior axillary fold will be at a higher level compared to the normal side
There will be increase in the axillary circumference

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding shoulder dislocation is false?
questions.solution:
OPTION C IS WRONG AS The anterior axillary fold will be at a LOWER level compared to the normal side REST ALL OPTIONS ARE CORRECT.

a) Anterior dislocation: In this injury, the head of the humerus comes out of the glenoid cavity and lies anteriorly. It may be further classified into three subtypes depending on the position of the dislocated head (Fig-13.4).

  • Preglenoid: The head lies in front of the glenoid.
  • Subcoracoid: The head lies below the coracoid process. Most common type of dislocation.
  • Subclavicular: The head lies below the clavicle.

b) Posterior dislocation: In this injury, the head of the humerus comes to lie posteriorly, behind the glenoid.

c) Luxatio erecta (inferior dislocation): This is a rare type, where the head comes to lie in the subglenoid position.


On examination: The patient keeps his arm abducted. The normal round contour of the shoulder joint is lost, and it becomes flattened. On careful inspection, one may notice fullness below the clavicle due to the displaced head. This can be felt by rotating the arm.

The following are some of the signs, associated with anterior dislocation mostly of academic significance:

  • Dugas' test: Inability to touch the opposite shoulder.

Reference- Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari, 7th edition, page no 88.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with the following X-ray after injuring his right forearm after a fall. Which nerve injury will you specifically rule out?
questions.solution:
Above image shows monteggia fracture dislocation.

Posterior interosseous nerve is the most commonly injured nerve, most commonly being involved in Type II and III monteggia fractures and proximal radius fracture. Fortunately, in most cases it is neuropraxia only and function returns within 3 months.

If no recovery is seen by 3 months; electromyography and nerve conduction tests show no signs of innervation, nerve should be explored.

Patient is having only finger drop which is suggestive of posterior interosseous nerve palsy which is a branch of radial nerve which can be injured during radial head fracture or radial head fracture fixation.

Reference - Rockwood and greens fracture in adults 9th edition, Page no 2345

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the OPD with history of fall. He has sustained injury to his hand and the x ray is given below. Identify the fracture.
questions.solution:
Above xray image shows Y shaped fracture of base of first metacarpal involving the volar aspect of ulnar and intra articular fracture.

BENNETT FRACTURE : It is a volar ulnar intra articular fracture.

ROLANDO'S FRACTURE: This is a complete articular,

Both the fractures resembles similar as ‘T’ or ‘Y’ shaped fracture at the first metacarpal.

  • Perfect reduction is not as important as in Bennett’s fracture dislocation.
  • Treatment is by accurate reduction and fixation with ‘K1’ wires and immobilisation in a thumb spica for 3 weeks.
  • The Bennett's fracture is a volar ulnar intra-articular fracture fragment of the metacarpal base with resultant subluxation of the remaining metacarpal shaft, which displaces proximally, radially, and dorsally. This occurs secondary to the pull of the abductor pollicis longus and adductor pollicis on the shaft fragment. The volar ulnar piece is often held in place by the palmar oblique ligament.
  • Rolando fractures are similar to Bennett's fractures but often result from a higher amount of energy imparted on the joint resulting in a Y- or T-shaped fracture pattern with more significant intra-articular extension. Purely ligamentous injuries to the thumb CMC joint are less common and a dorsal-radial dislocation may occur.

Reference - Maheshwari ortho 7th edition, Page no 115

questions.text: Identify the splint shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Above image shows Aeroplane spint (option C) and Knuckle bender splint (option B).

Ref- Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, Page no 26.

choices.text: Deciding on whether to do a traumatic amputation in a severely injured limb
Assessing the need for prophylactic fixation in a bone with impending pathological fracture
Assessing risk of shock in a patient with polytrauma

questions.text: In which situation is the Mirel's score used for?
questions.solution:
Mirels score is used to assess the need for prophylactic fixation in a bone with impending pathological fracture.


Each patient's situation is assessed by assigning a number (1, 2, or 3) to each aspect of his or her presentation (site, pain, lesion, and size) and then adding the numbers to obtain a total number to indicate the patient's risk for fracture. Mirels' data suggest that patients whose total number is 7 or less can be observed, but those with a number of 8 or more should have prophylactic internal fixation.

Option B:-DEXA SCAN is used to assess severity of osteoporosis.

Reference - Rockwood and Green's Fractures in Adults 9th edition, page no 1213

questions.text: Identify the cast shown in the image below
questions.solution:
Above shows patellar tendon bearing cast which is used to treat fracture shaft tibia fracture once fracture becomes sticky after 6 weeks of trauma

In case of shaft tibia fracture, first above knee slab is applied once fracture is stabilized with callus formation and fracture becomes sticky after that patellar tendon bearing cast is applied. And knee joint is mobilised.


Reference- Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 155.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions can give rise to 'Brown tumors'
questions.solution:
ORTHOPEDIC MANIFESTATIONS OF HYPERPARATHYROIDISM

  • Generalized osteopenia secondary to diffuse bone resorption
  • Generalized bone pains: - the bones may even be tender to palpation.
  • Pathological fractures: - Generally involve the dorsolumbar spine, neck and shaft of femur and pubic rami.
  • Brown tumours: - In regions where bone loss is particularly rapid; hemorrhage, reparative granulation tissue, and vascular, Fibrous tissue replaces the normal marrow, resulting in a brown tumor. Since hemosiderin is present in the area, it gives the characteristic brown color on histology. The lesion has a collection of osteoclasts and giant cells.

XRAY FEATURES OF Brown tumors: - Appear as expansile cystic lytic lesions seen mostly in mandible, maxilla, ribs, clavicle and pelvis. Multiple brown tumors may be present in advanced stage leading to multiple cysts scattered throughout the skeleton, a condition referred to as osteitis fibrosa cystica/Von Recklinghausen disease of bone.

Reference- Essential Orthopedics by maheshwari 7th edition, page no 304.

questions.text: A 50 year old carpenter has been working continuously in an under construction house for 1 month. He now complains of pain in the lateral aspect of his elbow. On examination, there is tenderness on the lateral epicondyle and Cozens test is positive. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow), a familiar term used to describe myriad symptoms around the lateral aspect of the elbow, occurs more frequently in nonathletes than athletes, with a peak incidence in the early fifth decade and has a nearly equal gender incidence.

Lateral epicondylitis can occur during activities that require repetitive supination and pronation of the forearm with the elbow in near full extension.

Microscopic findings show immature reparative tissue that resembles angiofibroblastic hyperplasia. The pathologic process mainly involves the origin of the extensor carpi radialis brevis but can involve the tendons of the extensor carpi radialis longus and the extensor digitorum communis.

One finds tenderness, precisely localised to the lateral epicondyle of the humerus. Pain is aggravated by putting the extensor tendons to a stretch; for example, by palmar-flexing the wrist and fingers with the forearm pronated. Elbow movements are normal. X-ray does not reveal any abnormality

Regardless of the underlying cause, nonoperative treatment is successful in 95% of patients with tennis elbow. Initial nonoperative treatment includes rest, ice, injections, and physical therapy with ultrasound, iontophoresis, electrical stimulation, manipulation, soft-tissue mobilization, friction massage, stretching and strengthening exercises, and counterforce bracing.

Option c -golfers elbow (Medial epicondylitis) This is a condition similar to tennis elbow where the inflammation is at the origin of the flexor tendons at the medial epicondyle of the humerus. Treatment is on the lines of a tennis elbow

Reference - Campbell Operative Orthopedics 14th edition, page no. 1411

choices.text: It is responsible for bone resorption
It produces alkaline phosphatase enzyme to lyse bone

questions.text: Which of the statements about osteoclast is false?
questions.solution:
It is wrong statement as osteoclast produces acid phosphatase.

Bone resorption requires the creation of acidic media via secretion of hydrogen ions (aided by ATP driven proton pump) around the ruffled border of osteoclasts in the sealed off clear zone. The process requires the enzyme carbonic anhydrase II to generate hydrogen ions. Acid phosphatase is produced by osteoclasts. These dissolve the alkaline mineral phase of bone.

Osteoclasts: These are multi-nucleate mesenchymal cells concerned with bone resorption. These have glycolytic acid hydrolases, collagenases and acid phosphatase enzymes.

These cells are activated by osteoblast. Their main function is to resorb bone and is thus involved in bone remodelling. Active osteoclasts are present in excavations in bone formed by them after erosion of matrix, the excavations being called as "Howship's lacunae".

"Ruffled border' - It is the cell surface in direct apposition to the bone with numerous infolding of the plasma membrane. Ruffled border disappears when the cell is in the resting state. The cytoplasmic region between the conglomerated nuclei and the ruffled border (site of bone resorption) is rich in carbonic anhydrase and in tartrate resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), lysosomes, mitochondria, vesicles and free ribosomes.

Ref- Essential Orthopedics by Manishkumar Varshney 1st edition, page no 12.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with fever and pain of both his legs for 10 days. He is a known case of sickle cell anemia and x rays taken show changes consistent with osteomyelitis in both his tibia. Which organism is most probably responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
SALMONELLA OSTEOMYELITIS

This occurs during the convalescent phase after an attack of typhoid fever. It is subacute type of osteomyelitis, usually occurring in the ulna, tibia, or vertebra. Often, multiple bones are affected, sometimes bilaterally symmetrical. The predominant radiological feature is a diaphyseal sclerosis. The disease occurs more commonly in children with sickle cell anaemia.

OPTION A-INCORRECT Most common cause of post-surgical, post-traumatic and osteomyelitis of the spine is Staphylococcus aureus.

  • Most common cause of osteomyelitis in drug abusers is Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

Reference- Essential Orthopedics by Manishkumar Varshney 1st edition, page no 128.

questions.text: A 6 year old child presented with discharging sinus in his right arm for the last 3 months. His x ray is given below. Identify the labelled structure.
questions.solution:
Above xray image shows bone within bone appearance.we can see dead bone in xray which is called sequestrum.

Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue trying to 'eat' the sequestrum away. It appears pale and has a smooth inner and rough outer surface because the latter is being constantly eroded by the surrounding granulation tissue.

Involucrum is the dense sclerotic bone overlying a sequestrum.

There may be some holes in the involucrum for pus to drain out. These holes are called cloacae. The bony cavities are lined by infected granulation tissue.

Now, after 2 weeks, acute osteomyelitis enters into the chronic phase. As periosteum is lifted, blood supply to underlying bone is damaged and a part of bone is rendered avascular. Avascular segment becomes dead, gets surrounded by infected granulation tissue and segregates from viable parent bone to form "sequestrum" (sequestrum means separated).

Lack of blood supply makes it difficult for body to halt infection, so body tries to wall off sequestrum by forming reactive new bone around it which is referred to as "involucrum" (Option B).

But the organisms in the sequestrum have proteolytic enzymes and create openings in the involucrum that are called as Cloaca. (option c)

Pus travels out from these cloacae out of the bone and finally out of the tissues and skin thereby creating openings in skin, forming sinuses, the clinical hallmark of chronic osteomyelitis.

Ref- Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 167.

questions.text: A 24-year-old athlete presents with complaints of pain in both feet and legs for the last 3 weeks. You suspect multiple stress fractures. What is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Stress fractures occur when normal bone is subjected to excessive and unaccustomed stress of lower magnitude than required for acute traumatic fracture (abrupt increase in duration and/or frequency and/or intensity of work). Stress fractures are common in lower limb bones in dancers, runners, jumpers, gymnast and military recruits.

TIBIA IS MOST COMMON SITE OF STRESS FRACTURE.

Pathophysiology

Repetitive cyclical loading alters bone’s microstructure and causes microfractures which lead to increase in osteoblastic and osteoclastic activity. When repetitive loading occurs at a rate at which body does not have time to recover, bone formation (osteoblastic activity) lags behind the bone resorption (osteoclastic activity). If the stress continues, fatigued bone may fail.

Clinical Features

After a period of stressful activity (athletic training, unaccustomed activity), patient presents with complaints of gradual development of pain at the site of stress fracture.

Box 1.12: Common sites of stress fractures


Radiology

It takes 2–3 weeks for the stress fracture to become visible on X-ray. Low-density cortical area (gray cortex) is the earliest sign. Later a radiolucent line extending across the cortex appears at the site of fracture. Periosteal new bone formation, linear sclerotic line or frank fracture line are late stage features (appear 2–3 months after the stress fracture). Bone scan [technetium-99m methylene diphosphonate (MDP) bone scan] shows increased activity and can show stress fracture in early stage.

MRI is the investigation of choice (IOC) for detection of stress fractures.

Treatment

Activity modification is enough for most of the stress fractures. For stress fractures of foot bones (metatarsals, navicular), no weight bearing below knee cast immobilization for 4–6 weeks is the treatment of choice. High-grade (MRI showing wide or transcortical increased signal intensity) tension-side (superior) femoral neck stress fracture requires prophylactic internal fixation with cancellous screws.

Reference- Fundamentals of Orthopedics by Mohindra and Jain 1st edition, page no 36.

questions.text: Which is not a part of the 'terrible triad of the elbow'?
questions.solution:
The terrible triad of the elbow is a severe elbow fracture-dislocation pattern with the following features:

  • posterior elbow dislocation
  • coronoid process fracture
  • radial head fracture

Reference-. Manish Kumar Varshney 1st edition, page no 979.

questions.text: Which is the nerve at risk due to the deformity shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown in the picture above is cubitus valgus. It is a late complication of non-union of lateral condylar fracture of the humerus. Diminished growth at the lateral side of distal humerus epiphysis results in a cubitus valgus deformity

It results in a late-onset ulnar palsy also called as tardy ulnar nerve palsy. Therefore, anaesthesia at the tip of the little finger, which is the zone of autonomous supply of ulnar nerve, is a feature.

The opposition of thumb is by opponens pollicis, innervated by a recurrent branch of the median nerve and not affected in cubitus valgus deformity.

TREATMENT: - At the earliest opportunity, the nerve should be transposed anteriorly from behind the medial epicondyle to prevent friction (anterior transposition of ulnar nerve).

Reference- Maheshwari Orthopedics 7th edition, page no 101.

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head

questions.text: An 18-year-old male, who is a known case of sickle cell anemia presented with pain of the right hip for the last 6 months. O/E, there is restriction of rotations of the hip joint. X ray shows crescent sign. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Here patient has restriction of rotation of hip joint and x-ray shows crescent sign which can be seen in avascular necrosis of femoral head.

Causes of avascular necrosis: -

  • Idiopathic most common cause
  • Coagulation disorder: Familial thrombophilias, hypolipoprotenemia, thrombocytopenic purpura, nephrotic syndrome
  • Thrombosis: Hemoglobinopathies (Sickle cell disease), storage disorders (Gaucher’s disease), pancreatitis, pregnancy, polycythemia, anticancer drugs, postrenal transplant
  • Embolic occlusion of vessels: Caisson's disease
  • Vasculitis: Irradiation, SLE (antiphospholipid antibodies)
  • Miscellaneous: High-dose steroid therapy, i.e. more than 2 g of prednisone or its equivalent for 2-3 months (occlusion of vessels by fat emboli and increased marrow pressure due to fat accumulation), alcohol intake, HIV, etc.

INVESTIGATIONS:

X-ray is usually the first investigation ordered that may be normal in the initial stages. As disease progresses, one may find patchy areas of increased density/sclerosis in the superolateral part of femoral head (as decalcification does not occur in avascular bone that appears white). As the disease progresses irregularity of the head, fragmentation and collapse may be noted. In the end stages, the joint space is lost and the hip ends up in secondary osteoarthritis.

Bone scan can provide an early diagnosis. Initially, there may be a hot spot and in later stages a cold spot.

Magnetic resonance imaging is the investigation of choice and provides the earliest diagnosis. In the initial stages, there may be edema in the marrow but as disease progresses, subchondral fracture lines (crescent sign) and eventually fragmentation and collapse may be noted. Other investigation tailored to cause may be needed.

Reference - Fundamentals of Orthopedics by Mohindra and Jain 1st edition, page no 365.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady, presented with pain of her left knee for the last 3 weeks. X ray shows calcification of the menisci and aspirate from the knee joint shows positively birefringent crystals. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
POSITIVELY BIREFRINGENT CRYSTALS ARE SEEN IN PSEUDOGOUT.

NEGATIVELY BIREFRINGENT CRYSTALS ARE SEEN IN GOUT.

Crystal analysis in GOUT: -

  • diagnosis made by joint aspiration and crystal analysis
  • monosodium urate (MSU) crystals are
    • thin, tapered, needle-shaped intracellular crystals
    • yellow when aligned parallel to red compensator
    • blue when aligned across the direction of polarization
    • strongly negatively birefringent

Pseudogout

Pseudogout is caused by calcium pyrophosphate dehydrate crystals, which are weakly birefringent positive on polarized microscopy.

Pseudogout most commonly affects the knee and, unlike gout, is more common in women than men. Polyarticular gout and pseudogout may mimic rheumatoid arthritis. The lack of symmetry, prolonged morning stiffness, positive serologies, and systemic symptoms may help differentiate polyarticular crystal arthropathy from rheumatoid arthritis.



Reference - Maheshwari Orthopedics 5th edition, page no 293

questions.text: An 11-year-old child underwent a contrast enhanced scan for which a dye was injected into a vein in her forearm. After 3 hours, she developed pain and swelling on the forearm, which was not subsiding on analgesics. O/E there is pain on stretching the fingers. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on clinical findings (pain swelling and pain on stretching of fingers suggests patient has developed compartment syndrome after injection of dye.

All signs and symptoms shows Patient is having compartment syndrome of the upper limb.

A history and clinical exam are the best tools to identify the diagnosis, and the treatment consists of emergent fasciotomies.

Compartment syndrome of the forearm may be secondary to trauma, burn, IV drug use, extravasation of IV fluids, or major limb revascularization.

The diagnosis is usually made with pain out of proportion to exam, particularly with passive stretch of the digits. It is possible to have compartment syndrome without neurovascular changes (paresthesia, pallor, pulselessness), particularly earlier in the presentation.

Compartment measurements may be obtained and are considered diagnostic with an absolute value greater than 30mmHg or when the compartment pressure is within 30mmHg of the patient's diastolic blood pressure.

However, pressure testing is not necessary in most cases, but may be particularly important in the patient who is obtunded, intubated, or who had a block, as the physical exam will be confounded. There are ten hand compartments: hypothenar, thenar, adductor pollicis, four dorsal interosseous, and three palmar interosseous; and emergent surgical release of all ten compartments is indicated.

Reference-  Maheshwari Orthopedics 7th edition, page number 47.

choices.text: Delayed union due to old age

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady had sustained Colle's fracture 2 months back which was treated with a POP cast. Plaster was then removed and a X ray taken, which showed a well united fracture with some osteopenia. But patient developed pain out of proportion, stiffness and swelling of her hand and wrist and shiny skin. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
All clinical features are of reflex sympathetic dystrophy.

REFLEX SYMPATHETIC DYSTROPHY

(SUDECK'S DYSTROPHY)

This is a term given to a group of vague painful conditions observed as a sequelae of trauma. The trauma is sometimes relatively minor, and hence symptoms and signs are out of proportion to the trauma.

Consequences: Clinical features consist of pain, hyperaesthesia, tenderness and swelling. Skin becomes red, shiny and warm in early stage.

Progressive atrophy of the skin, muscles and nails occur in the later stage. Joint deformities and stiffness ensues. X-ray shows characteristic spotty rarefaction.

Treatment: It is a difficult condition to explain to the patient, and also the treatment is prolonged. Physiotherapy constitutes the principle modality of treatment. Further trauma in the form of an operation or forceful mobilisation is detrimental. In some cases, beta blockers have been shown to produce good response. In resistant cases, sympathetic blocks may aid in recovery. Prolonged physiotherapy and patience on the part of the doctor and the patient is usually rewarding.

Reference-Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition page no 52.

questions.text: Identify the injury seen in the x ray below.
questions.solution:
Open book fracture: A pelvic fracture due to anteroposterior compression of pelvis where the pubic symphysis is disrupted and pelvis opens up like a book.

Dashboard fracture: A fracture of posterior lip of the acetabulum, often associated with posterior dislocation of the hip (other concomitant injuries can involve femoral condyles, patella and Posterior cruciate ligament).

Straddle fracture: Bilateral superior and inferior pubic rami fractures.

Malgaigne’s fracture: A type of pelvis fracture due to side-to-side compression of pelvis where there is fracture of pubic rami anteriorly and sacroiliac joint or ilium posteriorly but on the same side.

Bucket handle fracture: A type of pelvis fracture due to side-to-side compression of pelvis where there is fracture of pubic rami anteriorly and sacroiliac joint or ilium posteriorly but on the opposite side.

Crescent fracture: Iliac wing fracture in pelvis that enters into SI joint

Reference - Rockwood and greens fracture in adults 9th edition, page no 3207.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents to the emergency department with history of fall. An x ray was taken, which showed fracture neck of femur. There was no associated osteoarthritis of the hip. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
HERE AGE IS MORE THAN 60 AND THERE IS NO OSTEOARTHRITIS OF HIP JOINT SO HEMIARTHROPLASTY IS TREATMENT OF CHOICE.TOTAL HIP REPLACEMENT IS NOT REQUIRED IN THIS CASE.



Reference - Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 135.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with a swelling in the right leg for the last 3 months. His x ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Above xray image shows sunray appearance which is seen in osteosarcoma.

Following features are seen in osteosarcoma: -

  • An area of irregular destruction in the metaphysis, sometimes overshadowed by the new bone formation. The cortex overlying the lesion is eroded. There is new bone formation in the matrix of the tumour.
  • Periosteal reaction: As the tumour lifts the periosteum, it incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction in an osteosarcoma is irregular, unlike in osteomyelitis where it is smooth and in layers.
  • Codman’s triangle: A triangular area of subperiosteal new bone is seen at the tumour-host cortex junction at the ends of the tumour.
  • Sun-ray appearance: As the periosteum is unable to contain the tumour, the tumour grows into the overlying soft tissues. New bone is laid down along the blood vessels within the tumour growing centrifugally.

Reference-Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 240.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, who recently gave birth to a baby via normal delivery, presents with paresthesia and burning sensation on the front and outer aspect of her right thigh. Which nerve injury could have caused this?
questions.solution:
MERALGIA PARAESTHETICA

This is a feeling of tingling, burning, and numbness in the skin supplied by the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh as it gets entrapped in the fascia just medial to the anterior superior iliac spine.

Treatment is non-specific with analgesics, local hydrocortisone etc. Sometimes, surgical decompression of the nerve may be required.

Reference - Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 305.

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical changes can be seen in rickets?
questions.solution: Reference - Manish Kumar Varshney 1st edition, page no-72

questions.text:
A 9-year-old child presented with a pain on the left arm for 1 month. Her x ray is given below.

What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Above xray image shows fallen leaf sign which is seen in simple bone cyst

Solitary bone cyst is the diagnosis of a 12 years old boy, who presents with a symmetric, expansile cystic lesion in the proximal humerus.

Solitary Bone Cyst (Unicameral Bone Cyst) Common in first two decades primarily between 5-15 years

More common in males (2:1)

MC site: Proximal humerus (50-60%) >Femur (25-30%)

It is not a true cyst because not lined by endothelial cells but lined by fibrous tissue and blood vessels

Clinical Features: Asymptomatic unless presents as a fracture

Radiological Investigations: Cyst appears as centrally radiolucent lesions, on the metaphyseal side of the growth plate of a long bone Cortex is thinned but intact "Fallen fragment sign" may present indication that the lesion is fluid filled rather than solid. No cortical destruction

Other tests are usually not required except in unusual locations such as pelvis. In such locations MRI or CT is indicated.

HISTOLOGY- Cyst filled with straw-colored fluid and has thin fibrovascular lining.

Treatment:

  • Curettage
  • Methylprednisolone acetate injection into lesion
  • Intralesional injection of sclerosing agents

Reference - Maheshwari Orthopedics 5th edition, page no 249

questions.text: A 35-year-old male sustains injury to his right knee after a RTA. His x ray is given below. What is the treatment of choice in this situation?
questions.solution:
Above x-ray shows patella fracture which is displaced which requires surgical intervention (patellar tension band wiring).

CT images show transverse fracture of patella which is displaced

Nonoperative treatment for patella fracture: - Knee immobilized in extension (knee immobilizer, hinged knee brace or cast)

Indications: -

  • Intact extensor mechanism (patient able to perform straight leg raise)
  • nondisplaced or minimally displaced fractures
  • significant medical comorbidities

Operative (open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF)) Indications: -

  • extensor mechanism failure (unable to perform straight leg raise)
  • open fractures
  • fracture articular step-off > 2-3 mm
  • displaced articular patella gap > 3 mm
  • loose bodies
  • osteochondral fracture

Reference - Maheshwari Orthopedics 7th edition, page no. 145

questions.text: Which of the following bones is involved in 'snow boarder's fracture'?
At which of the following sites, does the Jones fracture occur?
questions.solution:
JONES FRACTURE: -

This is a fracture at the base of the 5th metatarsal, caused by the pull exerted by the tendon of the peroneus brevis muscle inserted on it. Clinically, there is pain, swelling and tenderness at the outer border of the foot, most marked at the base of the 5th metatarsal. Diagnosis is easily confirmed on X-ray. Treatment is by a below-knee walking plaster cast for 3 weeks.


REF- ESSENTIAL ORTHOPEDICS by MAHESHWARI 7TH EDITION, PAGE NO. 166

questions.text: Match the following table correctly.
questions.solution:
Fibrous dysplasia -gs alpha mutation causes fibrous dysplasia

Ewings sarcoma- on electron microscopy, are positive for MIC-2 gene and also demonstrate the trl (11;22) seen in the PNET group.

HME- EXT gene mutation seen in HME

Synovial sarcoma-translocation X:18 is associated with synovial sarcoma.

Reference: Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 5th Edition, Page no. 243

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents after a RTA. He has sustained a fracture of the right femur. There is a wound of 6 cm over the medial aspect of the right thigh with the complete transection of the femoral artery. What is the Gustilo Anderson classification?
questions.solution:
HERE complete transaction of femoral artery is present so it is grade IIIc injury.

If there is arterial injury that needs to be repaired, regardless of the amount of other soft tissue damage, it is considered as grade IIIC


Reference - Apley’s System of Orthopaedics, 9th ed. pg. 706

choices.text: Sensory loss in the sole of foot

questions.text: What is the earliest sign of TB paraplegia?
questions.solution:
ORDER OF NEUROLOGICAL INVOLVEMENT in tb paraplegia

Rarely is paraplegia the presenting symptom. Motor system is almost always affected before the sensory system because diseased area in spine (i.e. vertebral body) lies anterior to the cord near the motor tracts (Fig. 5.28). the first neurological sign is ankle clonus followed by plantar extensor. Thereafter the patient develops mild spastic motor weakness manifesting as clumpsiness or incoordination of gait which ends in severe weakness to the extent where patient is unable to stand and is bed ridden. the sensations carried by lateral spinothalamic tract-pain, crude touch and temperature are affected first followed by sensations carried by dorsal column-vibration and proprioception. Lastly, there is paralysis of anal sphincter and bladder. In extremely severe cases, spasticity disappears and paralysis becomes flaccid.

Reference - Fundamentals of Orthopedics by Mohindra and Jain 1st edition page no 241.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with bilateral knee pain on walking for a long time, climbing stairs and squatting. He has deformities of both knees as shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Above clinical image shows bilateral genu varum deformity of knee joint which is seen in osteoarthritis of knee joint.

In rheumatoid arthritis valgus deformity is seen not varum.


Reference: Manish Kumar Varshney 1st edition, Page number 375

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady who has been suffering from rheumatoid arthritis for the last 10 years, presents to you with the following deformity. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Deformities in RA

BOUTONNIERE DEFORMITY: -

Boutonniere deformity occurs when the proximal interphalangeal joint of a finger is flexed and the distal joint is extended.


SWAN NECK DEFORMITY: -

Swan Neck Deformities are seen with rheumatoid arthritis, characterized by hyperextension of the PIP joint and flexion of the DIP joint due to an imbalance of muscle forces on the PIP.


RHEUMATOID NODULES: -

Rheumatoid nodules are firm lumps that appear under the skin in up to 20% of patients with RA. They usually occur overexposed joints that are subject to trauma, such as the finger joints and elbows.


HITCHHIKER THUMB DEFORMITY: -

Hitchhiker thumb deformity is a musculoskeletal manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis presenting in the thumb, with the combination of: flexion of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint, hyperextension of the interphalangeal (IP) joint

It is also known as Z deformity of thumb


Reference – Essential Orthopedics Maheshwari 5th edition, page no 288

choices.text: Destruction of the distal radial physis

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with a progressive deformity of her left wrist. Clinical image is given below. What could be the pathological structure causing this condition?
questions.solution:
Above clinical image shows dorsal dislocation of ulna which is seen in madelung deformity.

Madelung's deformity: Defective growth of the distal radial epiphysis resulting in deformity of the distal end of the radius, and dislocation of the head of the ulna, dorsally.

  • Madelung's Deformity is a congenital dyschondrosis of the distal radial physis that leads to partial deficiency of growth of the distal radial physis.

In this deformity the lower end of radius curves forwards carrying with it the carpus and the hand but leaving the ulna sticking out on the back of the wrist. the left out ulna can be balloted like a piano key (Piano key sign).

The deformity may be congenital or post-traumatic. In congenital type also even though the pathology is present since birth, the deformity becomes obvious by 10 years as growth occurs. Function is excellent and only severe cases need corrective osteotomy.

Reference – Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 220.

questions.text: Which of the following marked areas is the most common site of origin of TB hip?
questions.solution:
The usual initial lesion is in the bone adjacent to the joint i.e., either the acetabulum or the head of the femur (osseous tuberculosis)

Most common site of extraspinal TB is hip. The initial focus starts in acetabular roof (most common), epiphysis, metaphysis (area called as Babecock’s triangle) or in greater trochanter. If the disease starts in acetabulum, the joint involvement is late and mild in severity. Rarely the disease may start in synovium and involve the bones lately.

REF- Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 193.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old patient with pre-existing comorbidities presents to the OPD with back pain. His x ray is given below.

What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ABOVE CLINICAL IMAGE SHOWS RUGGER JERSY SPINE.

RUGGER JERSY SPINE is seen in RENAL OSTEODYSTROPHY.

Renal osteodystrophy is characterized by bone mineralization deficiency due to the electrolyte and endocrine abnormalities associated with chronic kidney disease. The pathogenesis of renal osteodystrophy is multifactorial.

Hypocalcemia occurs due to the inability of the damaged kidney to convert vitamin D3 into its active form, calcitriol. The hypocalcemia and lack of phosphate excretion by the damaged kidney causes hyperparathyroidism and secondary hyperphosphatemia.


Reference- Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7h edition, page no 303

questions.text: What is 'carries sicca'?
questions.solution:
Tuberculosis shoulder (Caries Sicca): This tends to be the granular dry type of lesion without any pus formation and osseous destruction. However, range of motion is markedly restricted. the presentation is almost indistinguishable from frozen shoulder and must be kept as a possible differential in such patients.

Shoulder joint tuberculosis, at times, may not produce any pus etc., and hence is called 'caries sicca' and should always be considered in differential diagnosis of much commoner shoulder problem - 'frozen shoulder'.

Reference – Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 199

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady, known case of hypothyroidism, presents with pain on the base of right thumb for the last 3 months. O/E there is tenderness over the radial styloid and Finkelstein test is positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Finkelstein test is used to diagnose de quervain tenosynovitis

de QUERVAIN'S TENOSYNOVITIS

This is a condition characterised by pain and swelling over the radial styloid process. It results from inflammation of the common sheath of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons.



On examination, the tenderness is localised to the radial styloid process. Pain is aggravated by adducting the thumb across the palm and forcing ulnar deviation and on asking the patient to perform radial deviation against resistance (Finkelstein's test). There may be a palpable thickening of the sheath.

TREATMENT

In early stage, rest to the wrist in a crepe bandage or a slab, analgesics and ultrasonic radiation may bring relief. In some cases, a local infiltration of hydrocortisone is required. A chronic case may need slitting and excision of a part of the tendon sheath.

Reference – Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 295.

questions.text: Which part of the meniscus has the least vascularity?
questions.solution:
White zone (inner third) has least vascularity as shown in cross section of meniscus below.

Frontal section of medial compartment of knee.



Branching radial vessels from perimeniscal capillary plexus (PCP) can be seen penetrating peripheral border of medial meniscus. F, Femur; T, tibia.

Three zones of meniscal vascularity are shown:

  1. RR, red-red is fully within vascular area;
  2. RW, red-white is at border of vascular area; and
  3. WW, white-white is within avascular area.

Reference - From Arnoczky SP, Warren RF: Microvasculature of the human meniscus, Am J Sports Med 10:90, 1982;

Campbell operative orthopedics 14th edition page no 2212.

questions.text: Which is the last deformity corrected in the Ponseti method of managing CTEV?
questions.solution:
Equinus deformity is corrected lastly.

Ponseti method of choice now with a success rate of > 95%. This procedure consists of manipulating the foot for 1-3 minutes into corrected position, followed by holding the correction in an above knee cast (applied with knees flexed to 90°).

After 7 days, cast is removed, foot re-manipulated, and recasted for another week in successively more corrected position. Usually 5 to 7 casts are sufficient and deformity gets corrected.

The order of correction is very important. It can be remembered by the pneumonic

"CAVE". Cavus is corrected in the 1st cast by supinating the forefoot and dorsiexing the 1rst metatarsal.

Forefoot must never be pronated as it will increase the cavus deformity. Adduction and varus are then corrected simultaneously in the subsequent casts by abducting the forefoot in supination with counter pressure being applied at talar head.

Lastly, equinus is corrected, by dorsiflexing the fully abducted foot.

In case dorsiflexion is difficult beyond neutral then a percutaneous tenotomy of Tendo Achilles is done to achieve adequate dorsiflexion.

Reference- Essential Orthopedics By Maheshwari 7th Edition, Page No 210.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl fell from her bed and sustained injury to her right wrist. X ray shows a fracture line at the distal radius physis with a triangular metaphyseal fragment. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Salter Harris system remains the most widely used system for describing physeal fractures.

Conveniently the Salter-Harris types can be remembered by the mnemonic SALTR.

type I: - Slipped (5-7%)

fracture plane passes all the way through the growth plate, not involving bone cannot occur if the growth plate is fused.

type II: - Above (75%) (by far the most common)

fracture passes across most of the growth plate and up through the metaphysis

type III: - Lower (7-10%)

fracture plane passes some distance along with the growth plate and down through the epiphysis poorer prognosis as the proliferative and reserve zones are interrupted

type IV: - Through or transverse or together (intra-articular)

fracture plane passes directly through the metaphysis, growth plate and down through the epiphysis

poor prognosis as the proliferative and reserve zones are interrupted

type V: -ruined or rammed (uncommon <1%)

crushing type injury does not displace the growth plate but damages it by direct compression worst prognosis.

type VI: injury to the perichondral structures

type VII: isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate

type VIII: isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification

type IX: injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

Reference- Fundamentals of Orthopedics by Mohindra and Jain, page no 19.

questions.text:
Sangeetha gave birth to her first child 2 days back. She was informed by the doctor that the delivery was difficult as the shoulder of the child was stuck in the birth canal. Now, she noticed that the baby was not moving his LEFT upper limb very well and there was a deformity as seen in the image.

What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Above image shows policeman tip deformity which is seen in Erb's palsy

Erb's palsy is injury to the upper trunk C5 and c6 of brachial plexus.

The upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5 and C6) is most frequently injured, resulting in Erb palsy, which is characterized by the "waiter's tip" posture. Erb's palsy is the most common form of BRBPP.

This is due to:

  • Weak abductors and external rotators of the shoulder + weak flexors and supinators of the elbow + weak radial extensors
  • Good power in internal rotators and adductors of shoulder + elbow extensors and wrist flexors (all supplied by the middle trunk and C7)
  • Sensory loss occurs over the outer aspect of the arm and forearm.

Klumpke's palsy: -

it is type of lesion generally is caused by hyperabduction of the arm as in catching hold of a support while falling from height. the injury tears the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (mainly T1 and partly C8).

Muscles Paralyzed

  • Intrinsic muscles of the hand (lumbricals and interossei) due to T1 involvement
  • Ulnar flexors of the wrist due to C8 involvement.

Clinical Presentation

Paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of the hand causes the claw hand deformity. Horner’s syndrome may be associated due to injury to sympathetic fibers to head and neck that leave the spinal cord through T1. the sensations in a narrow zone on the medial side of the forearm and hand may be diminished.

Reference - Fundamentals of Orthopedics by Mohindra and Jain 1st edition, page no 220.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female who is a known case of hypothyroidism presents with paresthesia of the lateral 3 fingers for the last 6 months. O/E Durkan test is positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Durkan test is used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome.

Tests for carpal tunnel syndrome are:

Percussion test (Tinel sign): tapping over the median nerve at the mid axis of the wrist elicits electric-shock like discomfort at the site of the tap with paresthesias that radiate distally into the median nerve distribution (positive Tinel sign).

Phalen test (or Phalen maneuver): The Phalen maneuver provokes median nerve compression by active hyperflexion of the wrist; this test is considered positive if paresthesias in a median nerve distribution develop within 60 seconds.

Tourniquet test: The development of numbness and tingling in the fingers in median nerve distribution after an inflated blood pressure cuff is placed on the upper arm suggests carpal tunnel syndrome.

Durkan compression test: compression is applied to the median nerve for 30 seconds with the thumbs or an atomizer bulb attached to a manometer. Patients with carpal tunnel syndrome usually have symptoms of numbness, pain, or paresthesia in the median nerve distribution.

Reference – Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 5th edition, page no 303

choices.text: Barlow test is a provocative test
Ortolani test produces a click of entry
Barlow test produces a click of exit

questions.text: Find the false statement
questions.solution:
Ortolani test has 2 steps.it is false statement.

Special tests designed for early detection of CDH are 1) Barlow test 2) Ortolani test 

Barlow test: Consists of 2 parts

1st part: Hip & knee flexed & thighs gently adducted. Feel for abnormal posterior movement & sometimes dislocation with a distinct ‘clink’ of femoral head.

2nd part: Thighs are gently abducted. If the hip was dislocated earlier, a distinct clink will be heard & felt indicating reduction of dislocated hip.

Ortolani’s test: Similar to 2 nd part of Barlow’s test. Hip & knee flexed and thighs gently abducted. A click of entrance will be felt as the femoral head slips back into the acetabulum from the position of dislocation.


Reference - Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 216

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the orthopedic OPD with history of RTA. He complains of an abnormal projection of his right shoulder blade while pushing against a hard surface. Which nerve must have been injured?
questions.solution:
PATIENT HAS DEVELOPED WINGING F SCAPULA WHICH OCCURS BECAUSE OF DAMAGE TO LONG THORACIC NERVE

Winging of scapula: The vertebral border of the scapula becomes prominent when the patient tries to push against a wall. It occurs in paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle in long thoracic nerve palsy.

LONG THORACIC NERVE

Anatomy: The nerve arises from the ventral rami of C5, C6 and C7. It descends behind the brachial plexus on the lateral surface of the serratus anterior, which it supplies.

Test: The serratus anterior muscle can be examined by asking the patient to push against a wall with both hands. The medial border of the scapula on the affected side will become prominent (winging of scapula, Fig-10.8).


Reference- Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 66

questions.text: Fracture at which site in the odontoid process of C2, has a high risk of nonunion?
questions.solution:
ODONTOID fractures are classified by Anderson and D’Alonzo classification (Figs. 3.29A to C) into three types:

  1. Avulsion of apex of odontoid
  2. Fracture at junction of body and neck (high non-union rate) 3.29 b
  3. Fracture extends into the vertebral body of C2.

Reference - Fundamentals of Orthopedics by Mohindra and Jain, page no 167.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented to the OPD with generalized body ache and fatigue. The x ray of her pelvis showed 'Looser zones'. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Osteomalacia, which means softening of bones, is the adult counterpart of rickets. It is primarily due to deficiency of vitamin D.

This results in failure to replace the turnover of calcium and phosphorus in the organic matrix of bone. Hence, the bone content is demineralised and the bony substance is replaced by soft osteoid tissue.

CLINICAL FEATURES: - bone pain, muscular weakness, spontaneous fractures.

RADIOLOGY: -

  • Diffuse rarefaction of bones.
  • Looser's zone (pseudo-fractures): These are radiolucent zones occurring at sites of stress.
  • Common sites are the pubic rami, axillary border of scapula, ribs and the medial cortex of the neck of the femur.
  • Triradiate pelvis in females.
  • Codfish vertebrae
  • Protrusio-acetabuli i.e., the acetabulum protruding into the pelvis.

Serum: The serum calcium level is low, the phosphates are low and alkaline phosphatase high.

TREATMENT:-When osteomalacia is due to defective intake,vitamin D supplementation therapy, as for rickets,brings dramatic results. Vitamin D in daily maintenance doses of 400 I.U. is sufficient. If there is mal-absorption, higher dose or intramusculardose may be needed.

Reference – Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 306.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented to the casualty after a RTA with complaints of pain and deformity of the right hip. Diagrammatic representation of his clinical appearance is given below. Which nerve is at risk because of this injury?
questions.solution:
Above clinical image shows FABER Deformity which is seen in Anterior dislocation of hip joint during which femoral nerve is injured.


Reference – Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 126

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with back pain and back stiffness for the last 3 years. His x ray of the spine is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
On frontal radiographs, "Dagger sign" is the radio dense line that can be seen in some cases of ankylosing spondylitis. This is due to ossification of the interspinous or supraspinous ligament. The corresponding sign is so named because the ossification is linear and tapers to a sharp point like that of a dagger. The dagger sign classically occurs in the lumbar region of the spine.

X-RAY FINDINGS IN ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

Bilateral symmetrical sacroiliitis is the hallmark of AS.

X-ray signs develop first on the iliac side of SI joint. Haziness and widening of SI joint due to subchondral erosions are the earliest X-ray signs. This is usually accompanied by variable osteoporosis around the SI joint.

As the disease progresses sclerosis, new bone formation and calcification of SI and sacrotuberous ligaments around SI joint occurs leading to ankylosis (fibrous then bony) of the SI joint as the end result.

Radiographs of the lumbosacral spine show loss of lumbar lordosis, diffuse osteoporosis, calcification of anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments, squaring of the vertebral bodies and bridging osteophytes (k/a syndesmophytes).

Eventually, the spine in advanced stages gives the classical bamboo spine appearance


Dagger sign refers to a single central radio dense line in the anteroposterior (AP) radiographs of spine related to ossification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments


Reference – Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 288

questions.text: A 59-year-old patient presents with weakness of grip in his right hand after a fall. The test shown in the image below is positive. Which nerve is injured?
questions.solution:
TEST SHOWN IN ABOVE IMAGE IS CARD TEST WHICH IS USED TO CHECK PALMAR INTEROSSEI MUSCLE,

For ulnar nerve,


Remember

A-adductor pollicus

B-book test –for adductor pollicis

C-card test –to check palmar interossei

E- egawa test - to check dorsal interossei

F- froment sign.

Reference – Essential Orthopedics by Maheshwari 7th edition, page no 67
